Alejandro Amenabar's supernatural psychological horror film The Others (2001) is a masterclass in filmmaking and acting. A modern horror classic for fans of The Sixth Sense, The Village, The Shining, Mulholland Drive, and A Ghost Story. Amenabar's writing is refreshingly heartfelt for a horror movie with a dramatic tale of love, grief, loss, isolation, paranoia, spirituality, and hope all centered as themes. You are constantly tense on edge waiting for a jump scare, but rather you are pleasantly gifted with scary situations and nerve-racking suspense instead. Amenabar's direction is stunning and focused on pulling emotions out of you, so that you feel both frightened and devastated during The Others' brief 101 minute run-time. He even composed the score for The Others to ensure a spooky atmosphere and unnerving vibe at all times.

Nicole Kidman's lead actress performance as Grace Stewart is riveting in one of her most powerful dramatic roles. Kidman cries, shrieks, and glares her way into your heart. You feel for her lonely woman stuck living with her frail children in her massive mansion. Kidman finds the heart of her character's pain and keeps you engaged with her impressive accent, stern attitude, and vulnerable portrayal. You have to see Kidman's poignant acting in The Others!

Fionnula Flanagan is outstanding as the supporting actress opposite Kidman in The Others named Mrs. Bertha Mills. Her kindly nanny, diligent house maid, and curious soul make for an endearing character that keeps you guessing. Flanagan is just as intriguing as Eric Sykes as Mr. Edmund Tuttle the strange gardener. Elaine Cassidy is pretty and upsetting as the mute girl Lydia in her subtle depictions of uncertainty and sorrow. All three of these supporting characters contribute to The Others' overall mystery.

Christopher Eccleston gets a moving cameo as the post-traumatic stress disorder stricken husband to Kidman's Grace named Charles Stewart. His cold and broken portrayal of a soldier coming home from World War II a different man is striking and resonant. I am awe struck by his crying while Kidman is pouring her heart out to him during a sad confrontational scene.

Notably, The Others features two incredibly strong and convincing child actors. Alakina Mann is fun, adorable, monstrous, mean, playful, and gripping as Kidman's daughter Anne Stewart. You are captivated by her careful performance that gives an honest portrayal of a young girl trying to cope with her mother's madness. Likewise, James Bentley is wonderful as Nicholas Stewart in all his childish fear and cowardly persona. Bentley is empathetic as such a young boy caught in a scary situation. You truly believe his character feels every line with an unsettling fear.

Javier Aguirresarobe's cinematography is a stunning selection of dark moody faces and empty rooms. He captures the isolated, haunted feel in each shot. I love the way he frames Nicole Kidman's face in close-up shots, so that she feels both likable and strange in a dangerous ominous fashion. The use of dim natural lighting and slow panning shots is brilliantly effective at keeping The Others feeling frightful in the darkness. By the same note, Nacho Ruiz Capillas' editing is sleek and polished as The Others flows smoothly from room to room. His cuts are effortless and nicely paced, so that the audience may sit with these fascinating characters in their haunted house.

Furthermore, Benjamin Fernandez' production design offers a rich home with lavish furnishings and classy style for a Gothic setting and moody vibe. Sonia Grande's costumes feel period accurate and neat to look at, especially all of Kidman's beautiful dresses. Her clothing choices make The Others feel strict, rigid, conservative, religious, and memorable.

Lastly, The Others has a massive twist ending that's telegraphed and alluded to early on and throughout the movie, so that you can believe in the fantastic finale. The Others is simply a magnificent drama with a sublime horror story core.

There hasn't been a genuinely chilling good old-fashioned haunted house story since 1963's Robert Wise classic, The Haunting. However, with the success of The Sixth Sense, the ground was set to produce horror films that would leave you looking over your shoulder in a dark room, What we have in The Others is a twist to a age-old ghost story which is thoughtful and unexpected.

Nicole Kidman plays Grace Stewart, a young woman waiting for her husband to return from the now ended, Second World War. She is isolated in a grand old mansion with her two sick yet playful children. Because they suffer from photo-sensitive skin condition, they are unable to be exposed to any kind of sunlight. In order to stop any harm coming to her children, the house must be in pitch darkness throughout the day. This sets the scene perfectly in terms of a ghost story. The house is empty, with no servants (They left in a hurry for no reason) and the story begins with the arrival of three new servants.

This is an intelligent thriller which does have some exceedingly spooky moments. The proceedings are aided immensely by the screen performance of Nicole Kidman, who establishes a convincing character embodying all the turmoil of the emotions as the hauntings begin to escalate. The two child actors also play good supporting roles that is believable and charming. Christopher Eccleston makes a welcomed appearance as the shell-shocked husband who returns abruptly.

The actual atmosphere created in this film echoes that of Robert Wise's work, with the use of disembodied sounds and threatening dark corners. The house is chilling, to say the least. It is empty and full of dusty attics that are ideal settings for ghost stories. The tension builds to a point where you might suspect a ghost to jump out at the characters that are alone in a room. It doesn't help when a ghost is described as a nightmarish old hag either! This is not a story with slimy bug-eyed monsters that suck out your brains but an intelligent study of what frightens people. It's simply the basics of a darkened old Victorian room that still has the timeless resonance to scare you witless. You might say that this is clich√©d but this is genuinely frightening stuff. This is also a story of the people who live in the house as well. The hauntings exacerbate the psychological stress of Grace's situation with her sick children and the new servants are not exactly sympathetic to her either.

The final mention goes to the conclusion of the story. It was unexpected for me and you have your suspicions but the film manages to flip them around completely. It's not a twist like in Sixth Sense which some managed to see coming from the onset of the movie.

Said to be a simple horror film with a chilling twist, The Others sounded like a horror film with an interesting concept.

But I found myself disappointed with The Others in the end. The main issue I found was the fact that it constantly deviated back and fourth between being a horror film and being a drama. The horror themes in the film were too low-key in comparison the drama that the story kept focused on, and yet it tried to be both films. The Others wants to be both a legitimate horror film and a complex psychological drama, but director Alejandro Amenabar fails to find the appropriate balance to make it work. The issue is that the film has the potential to be a great horror film involving the mysteries of a haunting, but the story is too focused on protagonist Grace Stewart dealing with the drama of being an isolated mother waiting for the return of her husband while she attempts to take care of her children. While The Others could have been an innovative horror film, it is too focused on the drama surrounding the character Grace Stewart who I was unable to sympathise for which left the film absent of being compelling in my opinion.
Admittedly, the fact that The Others makes an attempt to create thrills through an eerie atmosphere in a more classic film style is admirable considering that the age we live in is focused more on blood and gore to create shocks. And there are some moments where I found the film to be chilling thanks to Alejandro Amenabar's ability to create a genuine horror atmosphere. So his role as director is good, but I failed to find the story that interesting. It was less about the horror than it was about the melodrama, and if it was more focused on building a chilling atmosphere than it was on trying to make its protagonist a deep character then it could have been good. The mix between horror and drama pleased a lot of critics, but I found it to be quite on the contrary and it was like a soap opera mixed with elements of the supernatural. I'm not a fan of soap operas, so I was not a fan of The Others either. And I really just could not understand what angle Alejandro Amenabar was taking on the story or why he was doing it which left me confused at the film and particularly its ending.
The performances of Alakina Mann and James Bentley were good, but I had trouble sympathising for their characters because I found them so annoying. They were loud and obnoxious children, and even when their mother attacked them I failed to care. So one of the issues with The Others is that some of the characters alienated me from the film.
The Others has a very slow pace consistently, but if it was more of a legitimate horror film than I would have been able to tolerate that and take the time to enjoy things as they developed at a natural pace. But unfortunately, the fact that the film kept deviating between being a dramatic character study and a horror film threw me off and made the 104 minute experience of The Others feel a lot longer and a lot less entertaining. The entire experience was dull for me which is a shame because The Others could have been a great horror film about a haunting in a large house, and its setting was terrific. I mean the house that the main characters live in is a huge and old with a feeling of isolation and genuine fear in the air, and it is all captured with fine cinematography techniques against a musical score which is intense and eerie. So The Others had a serious amount of potential. But it could not transcend the fact that it was really a drama film at heart, and as a drama it is absent of elements that are all that much compelling leaves it as a poor quality film. The drama comes from the turmoil that a wife and mother faces as she attempts to protect her children and wait for the return of her husband, but it has been covered in many superior films and this example of the subject matter does not meld with the horror themes all that well. Frankly, if The Others did not have such an iconic twist ending there would be little to actually separate it from the many superior films that it is similar to. Yet even with it, The Others does not make much of an impact. If I watched the film from the start with full awareness of its twist ending, it would be a lot less of an experience than it is now, but I do have to give it credit for its originality in that regard.
The Others' most positive aspect aside from the atmosphere in the film is the terrific lead performance from Nicole Kidman. Although I didn't really find the character that compelling because I found the entire film to be rather melodramatic, Nicole Kidman's performance is a psychologically troubled wife and mother was terrific. She captured the part very well and held the screen with a lot of emotionally frailty from start to finish. Her voice articulation had her capturing her character's accent genuinely well and the pure power in her line delivery had a lot of strength to it. Nicole Kidman's leading performance in The Others manages to make the story feel more realistic than it is set up to, and if I knew the pains of being a mother or a wife then perhaps I would have enjoyed the film more. Nicole Kidman made me feel confident of that.

But despite Nicole Kidman's tense portrayal, The Others goes back and fourth between classical horror and melodrama without finding a balance or maintaining any consistent entertainment value to make it stand out, regardless of its clever plot twist.

Holy plot twists! I didn't see that coming. I came to watching this film without thinking much about it. I will try to speak as little of the plot as possible in this review so as to not spoil it for you if you have yet to watch it. If you have, then I implore to not reveal anything regarding the plot in the comments. So, here is what I think about The Others. 

This is the premise of the story. Grace is a mother living in a huge mansion taking care of her two children, Nicholas and Anna, while her husband, Charles, is off fighting in World War II. Three new servants have arrived at their doorstep and the children claims that there are others in the house apart from them. Fearful for her pride and her faith, she chooses to deny the claim until strange things start happening to her. There are voices and noises and the mysterious new servants. All I can say after that is that the story culminates in plot twists, a satisfying climax, and a suitably emotional and conclusive ending. 

This movie is one of those rare films that actually effectively and convincingly utilises plot twists apart from The Sixth Sense, The Empire Strikes Back, The Game, Fight Club, Psycho, A Beautiful Mind (it would be effective in this film if one does not have prior knowledge of the mathematician John Nash) and Shutter Island. The screenplay is pretty good with well-developed characters and bits of clues here and there to later explain the plot twists at the climax. For a horror movie, it was surprisingly nominated for Best Original Screenplay at the BAFTA Awards. The acting is also brilliant. Nicole Kidman performs strongly as the ever-in-denial and fretful mother, who is both a devout Christian and overly loving and protective to her children who are both hyper sensitive to light. Fionnula Flanagan as the mysterious yet somewhat amiable servant Bertha Mills also offers quite a performance. 

On the technical side, visual effects are of course kept to a minimum here. One of the most notable aspects is the cinematography. Apart from capturing the rather dull and gloomy atmosphere of the English countryside, there are some interesting techniques used as well, such as the 90 degrees camera rotation across the room as the curtains are being drawn. The production design is quite exquisite as well, showing both the splendour and creepiness of a large and virtually empty English mansion. Director Alejandro Amenabar provides the music for his own movie and it is actually pretty good; sweeping and subtle at solemn moments and bone-chilling in those of terror. 

Overall, a surprisingly good take on the horror haunted house genre with effective plot twists and one which relies, not on gore and violence, or frightening imageries, but on atmosphere alone to creep.

There are only a couple of small spots within Amen√°bar's script that are rather improvable, but what stands as most prominent and more detrimental to the film are faults in such more major writing aspects as story structure, for although this film manages to come up with enough of a reasonable amount of dynamicity to keep you going, there's only so much you can do with a story this minimalist before things begin to plummet into repetition that does quite a deal of damage to the steam and helps in keeping the film from taking off as much as it probably should. Of course, while this film does stand to pick up more often, it's not like things were ever intended to stay all that consistently juiced, as this story is, as I said, just so minimalist, and often too much so for its own good, having one setting and only so much bite to the plot, thus creating a basic story layout that doesn't stand a chance of hitting too terribly much, yet still stands to hit more sharply in execution than it ultimately does. There is immediate blandness within the film's concepts, but what really hurts this film the most is Alejandro Amen√°bar's keeping faithful, as director, to his script's blandness by drying up the film's atmosphere all too often at times, to where the moments without thrills and chills that stand as quite possibly most abundant find themselves renered much too slow, if not just plain, well, dull. The film isn't a total bore, but it is dry and limp, with atmospheric blandness to bring more to attention the story blandness, exacerbated by other writing missteps that cut at this project time and again, until the final emerges as rather underwhelming. Regardless of this, for every misstep, there is a strength, and while the strengths don't hit quite hard enough for the final product to, as a whole, hit with as much strength as it should, they still stand as firm enough to engage you through and through, or at least sell you on this world.

Seeing as how this film's scope is quite limited, there's not really a whole lot of material for the art and production departments to work with, so don't go in expecting the piece of production-heavy spectacle that is such other 2001 films as "Fellowship of the Ring", but do expect the art direction and production designs to be buyable, as well as manipulative of the minimalist scope enough to supplement a sense of claustrophobia. The film doesn't always bite, yet there is generally a genuinely tight air of intrigue that brings this film to particular life, and is itself brought to life by both the art direction's and production design's aforementioned clever plays with the minimalism within the scope and the mostly pretty inspired and even fairly firm establishment of atmosphere by director Alejandro Amen√°bar. Amen√°bar's atmosphere is all too often perhaps a little bit too dry for its own good, but is never really bone-dry, having enough inspired kick to it to keep the slow spots from dulling out too tremendously, and when tensions really start to raise in the form of creepiness, or claustrophobia, or even all-out consequence, Amen√°bar drives the film under your skin and pulls you to the edge of your seat, engrossed and eager to see what is to happen next, if not actually a little bit shook up. Were Amen√°bar more inspired, both as writer and director, this film could have really compelled, yet as things stand, the writing and direction is generally decent, while the performances that also supplement the film's engagement value never cease to impress, for although there's really not too much for the performers to work with, most everyone is reasonably charismatic, with standouts including the young and believable Alakina Mann (Seriously, where in the world did she go?) and, of course, leading lady Nicole Kidman, whose emotionally inspired and also believable portrayal of a stern but fearful mother faced with bizarre forces that threaten her loved ones cuts through all of the unlikable traits within the Grace Stewart character, until only a compelling lead force is left standing. As I said, the rest of the film isn't quite as compelling as its lead's performance, yet such an engaging central character gets this film by quite a bit, and with resonance and intrigue pumping this film along further, the final product emerges still quite flawed, yet generally inspired enough to engage you through all of the missteps.

Overall, the film hits its cheesy occasions, but is hurt more by what it doesn't hit in the writing department, failing to product enough story dynamicity to dismiss repetition, let alone obscure the bland, minimalist story structure that Alejandro Amen√°bar, as director, executes dryly, if not dully, enough for the final product to stand as improvable, yet not so much so that it's not ultimately more engaging than not, as the art direction and production designs do a fine job of establishing claustrophobia to supplement the intrigue brought to life by Alejandro Amen√°bar, who also draws a fair bit of dramatic resonance, complimented by a reasonably memorable twist and, most of all, the charismatic performances - the most memorable of which being by young Alakina Mann and compelling leading lady Nicole Kidman - that go into making "The Others" an enjoyable thriller, even with its shortcomings.

The film itself takes us into a spiral sense that makes us keep on guessing what was happening for real and what was just in our mind through out the movie which is good. People say that old movies back then like The Haunting, House On Haunted Hill and Thirteen Ghosts perfected that art well this film raised the bar to beat.
